instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Capacitor blown HELP
threads.message:
HELP!!!! lol

is just a blown capacitor but since apparently the schematic and board view are not available yet, don't know which to put there :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Capacitor blown HELP
threads.message: You prob can just pull it and be ok even tho it's good practice to replace it. I'm definitely interested in the BV and Sch too if anyone has it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Capacitor blown HELP
threads.message: wait, you if I don't replace it, it will work fine?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Capacitor blown HELP
threads.message: Remove it to clear the short. No need to put it back. Also don't use comments, use a "reply".

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Capacitor blown HELP
threads.message: Yeah what Duke said basically just remove it and see if short is gone. If the cap is one of many on the line, just that one cap missing shouldn't affect anything.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Capacitor blown HELP
